description.text:
My take on a simpler extruder without gears or hobbed bolt. The PLA (3mm) is feed past the motorshaft and draged/pulled trough. Its intended for use with all kinds of hot-ends nad carriers.
Im working on my own Hob-end, but since its not a extruded product, or a digital design, its not on thingiverse.

The third version of my extruder that works without anything other than a steppermotor and the casing.
The extruder have been testing and is working, but not consistently enough. The stepper motor is nurled/scrached/sharpened so that it will drive the filament down to the hot end.
Sometimes the PLA is just scraped and stops moving and this problem needs to be fixed before the extruder is ready for use.
Im thinking about mounting a m3/4 bold to press the PLA onto the nurled shaft, but it does not seem to be needed at this time.
The wings are for mounting to the y-axis carrier on a reprap type of 3d printer. There are no holes to make it more useful in conjunction to other designs.

comments.text: It doesn't seem complete enough to be useful but AS-IS but it did trigger me wondering if anyone has successfully hobbed a stepper motor shaft.  (Very tiny machining) but it might do the job along with the PTFE tubing for the filament to slide through.  Some kind of tension adjustment is likely to be needed.  Sorry about he pun but I'd be hard-pressed to use an adjustable roller bearing and sandwich the filament between the shaft and the bearing.   Keep designing and building and who knows what cool things you will make. :-)

title: PiCam V2.1 Holder for reprap printer

description.text:
This holder allows fixation of a raspberry PiCam V2.1 to the X stepper motor (on my model the lower left screw hole was unused).

Holds the Picam at about the height of the hotend's nozzle.

As I am using OctoPi/OctoPrint I was alwas wondering how to best fixate the Camera to the Printer. You might need a longer flat cable between camera and raspberry depending where your raspberry is located. The camera will be moving with the Z-axis!

BTW: I stole a PiCam design somwhere here, but can't remember. If somebody recognises his/her PiCam module in my code please comment, I will set the "remixed from" properly!

Needed to alter the model to compensate for ABS shrinkage.
Need one screw to fit it to the NEMA stepper motor.

title: Power Block
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Needed a 12vdc electrical binding post for my Xterra and thought I could make it instead of buying one. I designed it in 123D Design and after printing it I went and bought some 1/4" stainless steel hardware (1/4" X 3/4" bolts, small 1/4" flat washers, 1/4" nuts). I pushed them in and then held the bolt in place with a nut, I then used 5 min epoxy to fill in the space behind the bolt head. This not only holds the bolt in place but it also electrically insulates the bolt from any metal it may be attached to. The bolt is a snug fit so there will not be any twisting of it inside the printed plastic.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed it with 100% infill so it was very strong and sturdy for use with either a lot of wires or a few large wires attached.
Post-Printing: Remove the supports from the inside of the hex area. Depending on your printer clean up any plastic that may have infringed on the openings.
I used 123D Design to design it and Simplify3D to print it.

author: MadVampy

title: IMAGE 2 STL 2 HEIGHTMAP MESH CONVERTER GENERATOR

description.text:
Use this program to have fast, Correct, Nice mesh made from images, in huge resolutions.

1/produce a high res STL with the given program,
2/import the mesh into Meshlab and tick boxes 1,2,3,4,5,7 of the quadratic edge collapse decimation filter
3/you have an awesome and correct mesh, better and faster than a lot of professional CNC programs out there.

you can then import into 3dsmax using quickweld option and run the mesh through 3dsmax 2016 ProOptimzer modifier set to 2 degrees for coplanar face decimation and devide the mesh by 20%....

The result is perfect mesh... As a test, step one gave me 62megs, step 2 gave me 15meg and step 4 gave me a very nice mesh of 2.5mb.

title: Tronxy X3 Z Brackets with Mount Plates

description.text:
I recommend using the adjustable version over this one. Adjusting the tension of the rollers to the 2020 will help remove Z banding. You can still get Z banding from other issues.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193688

Combined Z axis mount and bracket for the Tronxy X3 with captured nuts..
This is a remix of the Z mounts by falvarez and a bracket by badgeek found here
https://github.com/TronxyX3/Tronxy_X3_Replacement_Parts

In V3 I moved the brackets forward to make a little extra room for cool mods like idig3d's X tensioner. I also shaved 2 mm off the height of the mount and added a small cut out on the support for the brass nut. I flipped the brass nuts so it's flange supports the assembly instead of those little nuts.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2020468

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60

comments.text:
Yes, it is playable. Please see this video https://youtu.be/welBpNRTCks
If you print at the native size, it should work with a standard clarinet mouthpiece.
I can ask the guy in the video if he uses a specific mouthpiece, otherwise, I am unsure.
comments.author: rychrd

comments.text:
Have anyone been successfull playing on this, mine only makes a really high pitch tone and nothing else.
Or do you need to scale it??
I'm using a mouthpiece from a Bb Clarinet.
comments.author: EONTWINE

comments.text:
David replied to my question regarding playability. Here's what he said:
The B flat mouthpiece is the correct one to use. They are probably squeezing too hard with their mouth (embouchure). However, they may also have the reed placed incorrectly on the mouthpiece or have the wrong strength reed for their ability. Another possibility is that they are not closing the holes completely which would give the wrong sounds.
comments.author: EONTWINE

comments.author: Adrie1946

description.text:
This is my first original design I made in Fusion 360 for a Dual Extrusion Printer. I made this for my cousins who are huge Dallas Cowboys fans. Using Simplify3D's extrusion wizard lines up everything perfectly.

I have included the Fusion 360 Files if you want to add your own text.

Use the following tool change script to prevent colors from oozing between tool changes: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1467258. I used the M133 script for Sailfish and it worked great. You need to set your temperatures in the script and where you want the extruder to move during the tool change. Note: It will increase the print time but it's worth it for the clean print.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

No

author: rice9300

description.text:
Pied de support pour remplacer ceux d'origine pour un MacBook Pro.
Imprimer avec du filament flexible et les emboiter à la place de ceux d'origine, pas besoin de coller, il suffit de les faire rentrer en poussant avec un petit tournevis, c'est aussi pour ça qu'il faut du filament flexible qui puisse se contracter et reprendre sa place.

Support pad to replace the original ones for a MacBook Pro.
Print with flexible filament and nest in place of those original, no need to stick, just push them in with a small screwdriver, that is also why it requires flexible filament that can contract and resume its place.

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Flexible Filament

Added ribs around the inner shaft, spots for them to fall into on the inner rings, and made the top lock wider since the pieces have to maintain a fairly tight fit from one end of the tube to the other.

This object can be used to fix a camera having a 1/4 20 fixation hole.

i plan to use it to build a quick fix for my camera.

I have a secret to make it work correctly : when i print it, i wait until the print is finished, then , I do not let the printed rod cool down : i immediately screw the rod to my camera while it is still a bit hot. this does form the rod more accurately than if i let it cool down.
each time i have not done this procedure, the printing was a fail....
but , please, print and use at your own risks.

remixed_from.title: Cobra - Rear mounted cooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3.

title: Wanhao - Monoprice i3 V2.1 Cobra Cooler for Stock Fan

description.text:
I know a bunch of people are going to be getting shiny new i3 clones (Monoprice Maker Select or Wanhao i3) for Christmas this year, and I wanted to share an amalgamation of 3 different components that I put together.

The goal is to let you print just one part in order to rear-mount the fan on your Duplicator i3 V2.1 instead of stacking a bunch of adapters and rigging it up. This will not fit older versions of the Duplicator/Maker Select.

This cobra cooler accomplishes three things that weren't possible before:

It allows you to use the stock 40mm fan that came with your V2.1 i3
It mounts to the plastic bearing block that comes on your V2.1 i3
It's a one piece design that mounts rigidly with one 16mm M4 screw

Big shout out to tahustvedt for permission to share a derivative of his Cobra Cooler:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090433

Also to PerN84 for the nice fan adapter piece:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394003

And to raymnli for the fan adapter block:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1714338

I used a 4 x 16mm allen head screw to mount, but you could use a hex screw or philips, all would work the same (philips might be easiest).

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30

Notes:

Wall thickness 0.8.
Support overhang angle 55 degrees
10% support density
SUPPORT TOUCHING BUILD PLATE ONLY!

comments.text: Just made one with PLA using the recommended settings with the version of Cura that came with my Maker Select V2 bought direct from Monoprice just before Christmas. Turned out pretty bad with strings everywhere. Not faulting the design and am hoping installing this cooler will help with the strings. Think I should not have changed the support settings, supports were too thin do do any good and added to the string problem. My label just says V2, not sure what the difference is between it and what everyone is referring to the V2.1. Not sure if it's a V2 or a V2.1
comments.author: BobInOK

comments.text: Version #1 is now installed and seems to be working great. Had to hog out clearance for the bump in my bearing blocks but a Dremel took care of that pretty quick. Wished I was good enough with 3D CAD to make the change in the print but that is beyond my expertise at this point.
comments.author: BobInOK

comments.text: Printed this a while ago and just now got it mounted to my makerselect v2. Fits almost perfectly.
comments.author: Foxtrot121

comments.text: I tried on my MP Maker Select V2.1.  It has black plastic bearings surrounded by a metal sheath and a black plastic holder.  The Cobra does physically fit the two mount holes below the bottom bearings.  But the bearing is being held onto the frame from the other side of these holes on the extruder form.   Since these screw holes are filled from the other side they can't be used unless I used short screws that wouldn't go in very far.

comments.text: While I didn't run into any issues with the mounting holes, I've absolutely run into the issue with the arms touching the heat cartridge on my 2.1. It's a shame too, because I like the look of this fan upgrade the most over all the others I've seen.

comments.text: Try the T-Rex fan on Thingiverse.  You might still have to shrink or grow it a bit for your paticular bearing setup but it will use a 50mm rotary fan and with a bit of modifying clears all parts.  As I mentioned in another comment, there are apparently several different types of bearings that MP uses on the 2.1 version of the printers and you will likely have to modify any design a bit to accomodate them.  You will have to tell your slicer to not do more than 50-75% speed though with the 50mm rotary fan as it produces a lot more air than the 40mm square one.

This is an adjustable mount for the GTeng FPV watch to go on your radio.

NOTE 1:
(The watch and the directly connected mount can be removed from the rest of the mount by turning one of the little side pieces out of the way.)

NOTE 2:
(The strap has to be removed but keep the pins that hold the strap on. The pins will be used to hold the watch to the new mount.)

HOW TO:
To remove the pins, use a razor knife or some other thin blade like object, and push on the little ring on the pin. The pin will compress into the wrist band. Then repeat that to put the pins back in the mount.

EXPLANATION:
The mount connects to the lanyard loop on the radio. There is a mount base for either straight or horizontal lanyard loops.

HARDWARE NEEDED:
You will also need 4 M3 screws and 2 M3 nuts to assemble this mount.

description.text:
A simple mount for a pc fan to cool your prints, the distanse between holes is 82mm. and all holes are 4mm. in diameter. The print is very simple so that you can print it with a very basic printer, and it will help you get better more complex prints. Keep the fan off for the first layers, or you will have curling or delamination issues.

PS. Sorry for any spelling or grammar mistakes, I still have a lot english to learn.

Printer:

kossel mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2mm.

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I used 2mm walls and a brim to help the first layer stick to the bed, and i am using masking tape on the bed.

This is a 3 part model of a 15mm scale desert house for use in tabletop/wargame hobbies. The house is designed to open up for miniatures or other small objects to be placed inside.   
Print one each of a, b and c.   
The pictures of my print show it after being sprayed with a coat rustoleum textured paint. Unless you like wasting your money on paint that clogs after its first use, I don't recommend it.

title: Ducati Multistrada DVT Frame Bung
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a frame bung to cover the bolt holes in the frame of a Ducati Multistada DVT. This could easily be scaled to fit the frame holes of other Ducatis. Included files are one for the left hand side of the machine and one for the right as they are slightly different diameters.

Thanks to "ducati logo keychain" by filippo98 for the remixed logo.

Printer:

Malyan M200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30

Notes:

I printed this in ABS with a 10 line brim to improve plate adhesion, and at a 0.1 layer height and higher temperature to aid layer adhesion to help stop the "legs" snapping on insertion.

author: Twidds

title: Bench power supply DPS5015.08" / 2.2mm thick Acrylic case

description.text:
This is an Acrylic case for the DPS and DP line of power supply modules.

Any of the Grey box power supply modules here should fit this case : https://rdtech.aliexpress.com/store/923042

Note that the pictures are of aprototype design with a different front jack setup and put together with hot glue, I found that banana jacks had too much resistance for the high amps this power supply is capable of so I changed it. I also did not have acrylic glue at the time. Hot glue works great, but is ugly.

I don't have pictures of the newest version but picture it without the ugly glue and perfectly clear.

The case is designed around .08 inch or ~2,2mm thick acrylic sheets that can be purchased from home depot or lowes.

The main module sits on the front (duh) and the holes on the left side are for standard banana jacks for low current projects. The smaller holes on the right are for directly connected wires. These are highly recommended for high current items as they have much less resistance. For the DPS5015 12 gauge wires are recommended.

The hole on the back side is for a standard 60mm 5V fan for cooling if desired.

The holes on the bottom are for mounting the circuit board of the larger units. M3 screws are used to screw down the stock pegs the units come with.

The rectangle hole on the back is for an XT60 connector for the input power and the round hole above it is for a 20mm round power switch. You can find these on ebay by simply searching round power switch. The actual opening is 20.8mm.

Glue together, make sure that you have the front panel on the right way, it is easy to get it backwards.

You will need to glue this together, proper acrylic glue is recommended but super glue and even hot glue works fine if you are not worried about it looking pretty.

Designed with adobe illustrator

Designed with adobe illustrator

title: A6 Fan Duct Modified
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a slight modification of Nick Rimmer's Fan duct. I slanted the top to reduce howling and optimize airflow. I also made the fan's top dimensions larger since the original fan duct fell out on me during printing and damaged my 50MM fan. This print should make your fan duct a nice tight fit and keep it from falling out, possibly damaging your fan and/or your print. If you like the original fan but not the howling, this item is for YOU!

There are better fans ducts out there, but this is the "ideal" fan duct that should have been provided by ANET from the factory with the printer. It is basic, sized correctly, provides adequate cooling, and doesn't howl like the wolves.

If you're looking for a more sophisticated fan duct, consider one of my other ones:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1996843
or
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299474

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The supports inside the fan were tedious to remove but with some care it can be done. If you prefer, you can do without supports and just add more layers to the top to ensure you have a solid smooth top layer. I personally went with supports.

comments.text: This works perfectly upside down and a Brim of 15mm surrounding. No Supports needed! Watch my make for better understanding: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:342320

author: Dark_Planet

title: Hictop Prusa i3 Z Axis EndStop Mount System

description.text:
Here is a simple alternative z-stop that makes precision adjustments extremely easy. It was a disaster wrestling with the original system the printer came with. What an annoying headache! These two parts for my design attach to existing screw mounting holes. There's nothing super fancy about this design but it's very functional and I like printing it in black so it sorta blends in and looks like it came with it originally. You're going to need two 40mm M3 screws (I bought at ACE Hardware) for the top bracket and two 15mm or 20mm M3 screws for the bottom bracket. I also used a total of 10 nylon washers too. Now, all it takes to make any adjustments is a simple screw driver turn on the vertical M3 screw. The stop never moves. The vertical screw moves. I saw this generic concept on a couple other pages for other printers so I thought to design a unique system for my printer.

Note: My print bed is unusual. If you are using the standard print bed that came with the printer, you will probably need to edit the STL file for the bottom bracket that the endstop switch mounts too and make it around 1/2" - 1" shorter.

author: Sarah90

description.text:
Since I just gained the ability to 3D print, I wanted to try my hand at some simple modeling and figured I would be able to make some backup connectors for my gridwalls instead of wasting zip ties which is fucking annoying and wasteful.

The connector is modeled after the connectors from the STOR version of gridwalls, which I got at kmart. The one shown is printed in PLA.

Differences:

  • The bottom is solid, so you can't connect the walls with the inside of the connector like the ones from the box.

  • The 3D printed one is 2mm taller than the packaged version. So, I'll be using these primarily as my base proppers so I don't have to waste 6-8 from-the-box connectors supporting my display. I would not use mix of printed and boxed connectors because you will have a very slight imbalance. So yeah, print as many as you need for the base. Measure them after you're done printing just to be on the safe side.

  • My last photo shows a small discrepancy between the two in use. There is a small tapered gap from the base to the top of the cube because of the space within the connectors. It's pretty minor but if you're not into it, well you should know that beforehand. It doesn't affect my display as far as I can tell.

    I put some weight on the connector and fiddled with it and threw it around and tossed it on the floor and it's still in one piece. I'd print it either solid or at a very high infill so you're very sturdy. They print pretty quick. I TAKE NO FAULT FOR YOU USING THESE. If your display breaks, that's on you. You're using these at your own risk. I've tried to design this close and strong to the original design. This is a third party made design so you using these is all up to you. Please don't claim this design. Obviously it is modeled off something already, but it'd just be shitty of you.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

author: Philipp6400

description.text:
From the book LEO the Maker Prince:
http://www.leothemakerprince.com
http://www.amazon.com/LEO-Maker-Prince-Journeys-Printing/dp/1457183145
LEO said, "Draw me a sheep", and Carla did. The next thing you know, his nozzles heated up and his spools started spinning, and this is the sheep that emerged on this tray.

• Print the sheepWHITE file (sparse fill is OK).
  • Print the sheepBLACK file. (The upright version is newest and may print well without support.)
  • Clean support off of all files and insert the black parts into the white part. There is a nose, ears, and four legs.
  • Note that the legs should bend towards the inside of the body.
    • Here's a tip from Jen Adams at MakerBot: if you put the legs in most of the way (remember, they should curve inwards) and then put the sheep on a table surface and press gently down on the body, you can get the legs to snap in and fit snugly.

comments.text: Is there something I'm missing here with how to remove supports?  I'm using MakerWare and when using supports (for ANY print, not just this one) it is pretty much impossible to remove them... or is it that I'm just supposed to use an x-acto knife and pry away at it and then sand it to make it look nice?
comments.author: pcenginefx

comments.text: Hi pcenginefx! The process of removing supports is still a bit of an annoying reality as printers for home use are in a pioneering stage. Unfortunately it takes a bit of work with snips and an X-acto (and sometimes sanding) to get things looking really good. With high-end printers the supports can sometimes be made of a different material so that it dissolves away and leaves the good part behind, but with a low-end printer it takes elbow grease. Certain simple models that have a thick base come out well without supports, but anything a little complex will need them, as well as a raft, to get a good print.
comments.author: pcenginefx

comments.text: So finally came back to this thing and figured out a way to print the sheep.  I cut the sheep body in half using netfabb and printed both sides flat - pretty much solved my problem...now I have a perfect sheep!

title: Custom-fit Cabinet Child Lock - Simple and Beautiful

description.text:
A childproofing lock to make it very easy to cleanly and securely lock a pair of cabinet doors that open away from each other. This only works if both cabinets have knobs with cylindrical posts/spindles. Look at the pictures and it'll become more clear what's going on. Sorry, but this solution is not for every cabinet in the kitchen or bathroom--it's only specifically for those settings where two doors open opposite each other.

You'll need the diameter of the two spindles on the knobs and the distance between centers on the knobs as installed on the cabinets (measure with the doors closed). The demo stl is provided only for illustration purposes: you'll want to use your own numbers to measure your knobs and your doors to customize the stl for your cabinets. The rest of the parameters in the customizer can be left to defaults to start. Click "open in customizer" above and you'll get a chance to input your parameters and print your custom-fit cabinet lock.

The main reason I invented this is because the ones you can buy in the store are ugly and awkward! I really appreciate feedback on whether this works for you. Please take pictures and post if you get it working! Here's a search for other products that I considered before deciding that I really wanted to make my own design.

I prefer to print in PLA because if you want to easily adjust the tightness of the lock you just run the elbow under hot water for a minute and bend it a bit tighter or a bit looser. I'm sure you can print it in whatever you want, though. And the parameters in the OpenSCAD file also help you tune it for how tight you want the lock to be / how easy you want it to be to release and re-engage.

title: Laser Cut Police Box (aka TARDIS)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Model of the 1950's UK Police Box, also used by some for time travel. These were made for my children to play with and are built to scale with (most of) their existing figures. Cut on Kwartzlab Makerspace's G-Weike (http://kwartzlab.ca) laser cutter.

Made for 3mm material at least 300x300mm in size. This example is made from hardboard, but any 3mm laser-cuttable material can be used such as acrylic, cardboard, etc. Requires: Glue, paint, paper for inside windows and signage.

  • Lay out pieces with scorched side up. Note the two thick and two thin door frames which fit the base. Sequence is thick-thin-thick-thin. Inner doors nest inside each other. Broken outer-door centres can be glued back in place.

  • Build scorched side out. The base is asymmetric to fit the doors. A quick dry-fit will ensure parts to in the correct place. The door centres should be exactly centered with each other.

  • Itâ€™s easiest to build upside-down, placing the door panels in the roof. Make sure the outer door panel is pulled towards the top of the door frame.

  • Glue the bottom in place, then after about 15 minutes flip over and glue the top in place. The outer door frame may need some glue in the centres.

  • The door panels come in two sizes. Glue the outer edges, and place inside tight to the edges. Place the thick one first, then the thinner one tightly next to it.

  • There should be a gap for the next side door panel. Wait a couple minutes for glue to set, then rotate and do the next side.

  • Glue caps together, make sure all are aligned.

  • Paint. Cut paper to fit windows and glue to inside. Signage can be laser-printed and glued.

description.text:
These are spacers designed to mount a 220mm diameter hot bed to the Anycubic Kossel Linear (and other similar Kossel Delta printers). They're designed to fit a printer with 20x20x240mm extrusions (300mm triangle), using M4x10 socket headed screws and M4 square or T-nuts. The spacers are mounted 45mm from the end of the extrusion, and are shaped to fit the curvature of the bed at this position.

To provide clearance from the electronics, the spacers raise the hot bed 10mm above extrusion. The overall height is 13mm to be flush with the top surface of a 3mm thick hot bed.

There are two models: left and right handed, and 3x of each type need to be printed.

I've also added a PDF template for a heat shield, which is designed to sit between the electronics and hot bed. It has three rectangular feet which sit on the extrusion between each pair of spacers. For this I just used some 3mm hardboard covered in aluminium tape (as shown in one of the attached pictures).

After printing these, I also found these clips which work really well for mounting a 200mm glass bed to the heat plate: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1275136

Update 13/01/18: I've modified these to include a 3mm hole with a recess for an M3 nut (hotbed_spacer_02_right), and designed an additional clamp which fits on top of that (hotbed_clamp_02_right). I'm now using 3x of these with M3 countersunk screws and nuts to hold the bed down (i.e. only clamping the bed gently on 3x of the 6x spacers). My thinking is that this should be sufficient to hold the bed in place, without risk of distorting anything.

Update 25/01/18: I've added a new "tighter" version of the clamping piece, if you find the existing one a loose fit on your bed. The original fits perfectly and makes a tight fit on my own bed (which I just measured at 3.25mm thickness). However, the "tighter" version will be more suitable if your bed is less than 3mm thick.

It's a good idea to print these out of ABS rather than PLA so you can use higher bed temperatures for printing ABS, HIPS etc.

There were no instructions to install the heated bed. Using the Anycubic Trigorilla Ramps 1.4 compatible board, I connected a 12V 20A PSU to both the 11A and 5A power inputs, connected the bed to the HOTBED output (don't do this: read the warning below), and connected the heat bed thermistor (NTC 3950 100K) to the T1 sensor input. In the Marlin firmware, I configured TEMP_SENSOR_BED as type 11 (QWG-104F-3950 thermistor). The lookup table was missing from my older version of Marlin, so I added this table from the current Marlin development trunk.

WARNING: after running the heated bed successfully for quite a few weeks, the power MOSFET on my Trigorilla Ramps 1.4 board overheated (with a really nasty burning smell). On the Trigorilla board, it's an STB55NF06 MOSFET (B55NF06 GK162 V6 CHN 618) in DPAK surface mount packaging, and I guess it just doesn't have enough PCB copper area to dissipate the heat, resulting in thermal runaway. The plastic connector next to it also melted. Now I have to repair it, and I'm thinking of replacing with an external TO-220 packaged MOSFET with a decent heat sink. After this experience, I would not consider using the on-board MOSFET again...

I'm now using an external MOSFET board (HA210N06) instead of connecting direct to the Ramps board.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness

Infill:

20%

author: Sdstevenspe

description.text:
I set out to make a differential to understand how it allows an axle rotate at different speeds. It's my learning process and this open model helps show how a differential works. When printed and assembled together the pinion shaft(engine input) rotates causing the ring gear to rotate as well. In turn rotating the output shafts which go to the wheels. If one output shaft is held in place, and the input shaft is spinning the opposite shaft will still spin. Excellent model to show how it works as well as why a regular differential is bad for any offroading or winter conditions. If a wheel is on ice and the other wheel locked in place in some snow, the result will be all the rotational velocity diverted to the wheel on ice.

I hope you enjoy the model as I worked hard on it- learning CAD (solidworks)
any tolerances that don't work correctly please leave a comment.

You know your printer better than me- that being said I would still print the gears at 0.1mm layer height.
none of these prints required supports.
I would not recommend printing the stand in ABS- unless you got it down to a science.
also on the stand if you are printing at greater layer height i would include supports so the shaft holes print nicely.

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays A Bauhaus Chess inspired pieces with a possible game play twist. Each of the pieces can nest into the recess of any other piece. How will this twist effect game play? Perhaps a variant where when capturing a piece you stack on it and gain it's movement. Perhaps you can "capture" your own pieces to make a more powerful piece that you can dismount later. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/kViPVT8yuhX

• Print two plates in different colors or print the individual colors.
  • Make up your own rules for the stacking function.
  • Try out a game with someone.
  • Post the new rules and results in the comments below.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55821 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=55821

My dad loves puzzles, but its always a bummer when you finish the puzzle only to find a missing piece.

His latest puzzle was a tough one that he had done several times, and he really loves the trout shaped puzzle. He wanted to frame this one but couldn't without figuring out a replacement for a missing piece. My mom was going to cut it out of the picture on the box, but the puzzle and the lid were different scales.

So I decided to 3d print a replacement and use a color printout for the image.

See the instructable here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/3d-Printed-Replacement-Puzzle-Piece/

Make it 3D in Morphi App

Using the www.morphiapp.com "Sketch" tool, I imported the high contrast picture into Morphi. I then used "Transform" to get each axis to the correct size. Morphi provides an STL export so that I could slice the part for printing.

Ruler on in Morphi

remixed_from.author: Lalo_Solo
remixed_from.title: USB and SD card holder for wide USB sticks

description.text:
Tips in any amount are appreciated: https://www.paypal.me/satgod

A few people where asking for a larger one and after making the original I just figured why not so I mirrored the original and put a 12mm space between them to ensure enough room for wide usb sticks to be side by side and that was it.
All real credit should goto Lalo_Solo
I did increase the scale from 100% to 101.5% so that if your printing with a material the shrinks much (ABS) your stuff will still fit once it does shrink
For those using PLA or Petg if your printer is dialed in the items will be a little loose but only in the fact that they slide in and out without any resistance

After filling it up fairly quickly i'm think maybe I should have done 3 of them together at least for the usb part

This one holds:
16 USB
16 SD cards
10 Micro SD cards

print_settings.Notes:: Quality doesn't matter much on this print.  For one, it's not the thing on display, and for two, the thing will print a lot faster at larger layer heights.  There's no fine detail to capture, so that's fine.

description.text:
I wanted a rotating display stand for a printout of this ambiguous cylinder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1668263

I looked around on amazon and didn't like anything I found, so I whipped this up real quick in tinkercad and tossed an arduino nano and a cheap 9g servo at it. It's working pretty well so far. The cheap servo I threw in here does almost 180 degrees. Close enough for what I'm doing here.

Video of it actually working here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SnhmS1U0bKQ

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Quality doesn't matter much on this print. For one, it's not the thing on display, and for two, the thing will print a lot faster at larger layer heights. There's no fine detail to capture, so that's fine.

Print, tape, wire, glue.

Print out both pieces.
I added black duct tape on the surface of the rotating disc piece to keep things from sliding off.
Wiring diagram is attached as an image. Pieces are hotglued into the structure. See photos.

Parts:

arduino nano - $6ish on amazon, but you can find them for 2-3 bucks a piece if you're willing to buy a dozen or so from aliexpress/ebay.
https://smile.amazon.com/ATmega328P-Microcontroller-Board-Cable-Arduino/dp/B00NLAMS9C/

9g servo - $3ish each on amazon if you buy 5: https://smile.amazon.com/Genuine-Helicopter-Airplane-controls-TowerPro/dp/B019H9BNTQ/

Other than that, it's just wires. I tossed a 5V boost converter in and put plugs on all the connections because I like reusing my parts from old projects and it's easier if they have plugs. You could wire this with a lot less wire if wire management is your thing. I'm terrible about leaving too much wire in things.

Code is up at:
https://github.com/bobiam/rotobox

It's a slight modification of the sweep program. My servos aren't quite getting 180 degrees, but they're close enough for my purposes.

Built in Tinkercad, with source files available here:

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cDHnetI0y6V-rotoboxbase
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cfv2FyRuqTN-rotoboxlid

This is a fidget gear I created. The hardware is a number 8 nut and bolt I got from the home depot.

New version of the dimensional calibration tool.

The revised part is easier to measure, and should give more accurate results.
The spreadsheet now considers both scaling error due to shrinkage, as well as radial compensation error (horizontal size adjustment in S3D).

  1. Print the test part using your filament of choice, and slicer settings you intend to use.
  2. Measure and input into the spreadsheet (mine is shared at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/14Nqzy8B2T4-O4q95d4unt6nQt4gQbnZm_qMQ-7PzV_I/edit?usp=sharing).
  3. Update slicer settings.

The concept is to measure all but the smallest part feature. These larger features will be most affected by errors due to shrinkage, and least affected by errors due to radial compensation errors. The scaling error percentages are populated.

Next, measure the smallest feature. This feature is least affected by shrinkage, and most affected by radial comp errors. The spreadsheet estimates what the error 'should' have been based on the scaling errors found on the larger features, and attributes the difference to radial comp error. This radial error is populated.

Next, the spreadsheet recalculates the scaling errors found on the larger features by 'simulating' that you reprint the part with the radial comp adjusted, then takes an average of these values as the final scaling error for your slicer.

Lastly, at the bottom both the scaling factor to input and the radial shift (called horizontal size compensation in my slicer) are populated. Plug these into your slicer.

If you want it super accurate, you could run 2 iterations of this, but in my case once was good enough to get me to less than 100um over the 150mm part, which I was happy with.

Creator Pro

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing this. I had printed several parts that should have fit together and I had been relying on sanding to get them to mate.
Until seeing your project, I wasn't aware of the importance of the horizontal compensation.
I did have a problem measuring the 2 mm web using your design. My calipers were too fat to fit into the slots, so I had to modify your design and widen the slot.
I also found that I achieved better results when I calculated separate X and Y scaling factors. Mine differed by 0.72%. I assume that differing belt tensions caused the discrepancy.
Additionally, my printer rounded the small flat section of the diamond where the calipers are to measure. As a result, these values seemed wrong and I discarded them. Perhaps if I widened these areas, I could have included them but since I was already happy with the result, I didn't bother.
It might be obvious to experienced Simplify3D users, but I didn't know where to enter the scaling factors so that it would automatically be added. It turns out that it is hidden in Tools>Options>Models>Import Actions.

description.text: As RepRap has evolved it has acquired many tools and capabilities which have been developed and refined. Mostly this has been concentrated around plastic extrusion but tools exist for paste, metal, ink etc The next logical step in it's evolution would be to combine these capabilities to unlock further potential. Work is already ongoing on lots of multiple extruder designs on a single carriage. This is one potential solution. However I propose a Tool Changer! This is a work in progress and I will add more info as and when I get time. **First test of head changing http://youtu.be/-p9uMt9foKE **NEW Update nearly time to press print Close up of new extruder design and x carriage with sprung electrical connections. http://youtu.be/2qtQg9IiP5Q
Watch this space

author: mdmang

description.text:
Just print the yellow parts:

4x 125mm bar,
2x 150mm bar,
9x bar mount
(everything included in the lights.stl)

and attach all together with some glue.

The light angle of the bars is 30° downwards.

I bought some 12V 8mm "neutral white" led strips (3528) from ebay (http://www.ebay.de/itm/111115650134), separable into 5cm pieces. You need 2x 25cm and 1x 30cm (=80cm).

Connect to the 12V power supply using some 22AWG (0,33mm²) wire.

Enjoy! :-)

https://youtu.be/0iKLjEa282o

There is enough light for some cool videos!

description.text:
These gauntlets are an addition to my Exo-suit project that replace the original stirrup style hands. I've included a separate Cuff so they can be worn alone without rest of the suit.

Everything except the knuckle hardware can be printed at 20% infill with 0.6mm sides.
The Knuckle hardware needs to be printed at 100% infill.
Print at 20mm/sec or slower, max 0.2mm layer height and supports "everywhere".
I've included only one copy of each file. The fingers are the same from left to right hand. The thumb is the same but assembled opposite.

The end pieces of the fingers can break if bent too far when assembled.

Make sure the parts are clean of all supports, holes are cleaned out and the posts are round. Test fit and verify all parts before melting or gluing the retainers down.
Please follow the pictures for assembly instructions.

title: One Gauge Marklin 5900 Model Train Track Connector

description.text:
Track Connector for Marklin One Gauge 5900 type track.  
One Gauge (1 Gauge) track is fairly uncommon. It is large scale that is pretty much the width of "G Scale" but the cars are 1:32 in size. The One Gauge I have (Marklin 5900 300mm straight track) is also much 'shorter' with the rails only about 0.2 inches high, versus G Scale which is taller. This is a 40 year old set and the track connectors where loose and allowing the track to separate and cause derailments.  This snaps over the last two ties to keep the tracks together.

Printed with a PB+ sliced with Slic3r at 0.4 levels, three perimeters and .2 fill with PLA.  I print them with out a brim, though a brim gives it a bit more lip in the bottom to snap tighter.  I print them off 9 at a time on my  pB+.  My son thinks they look 'Christmas-y' in virgin PLA.  This is the first thing that I've measured, CAD'd and printed all in one iteration and it worked.

print_settings.Notes:: Temps were 200/60(Nozzle/Bed) for all PLA pieces.

description.text:
(FIRST THINGIVERSE PUBLICATION! YAY!)
I wanted to be able to have a precise way to control a Dremel tool and the aftermarket router bases that I saw for it were $50 -$100. I had a new Anet A8 and Sketchup, so in about two hours I went thru multiple iterations of designs to arrive at the final design and started printing it late that morning. I think this will fit a majority of the Dremel tools with the threaded ring at the tip.

It uses 1/4-20 carriage bolts (>4" long?) as vertical guides with two knurled knob adapters with 1/4-20 nuts to create an adjustable frame. Works like a charm.

After printing I drilled out the 1/4" holes on the base and the so they were a fit to my liking.

The threads for the Dremel were reuse from a different Thingiverse model by topias5 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1222591) and the knobs were a slimmed down version of Frugalshave's knob(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:177400).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

For the base I had issues with keeping it flat as I needed it to be.(PLA)
The third attempt at printing it I used a Raft base in Cura and that kept it flat, but required a lot of model cleanup at the end. I printed it with a light fill.

The Upper carriage I printed with a solid fill with the bottom oriented up to give the two components relatively flat mating surfaces when setting at the lowest level.

Temps were 200/60(Nozzle/Bed) for all PLA pieces.
Threads for the Dremel will require some careful cleanup, but the Dremel will eventually fit nicely.
Sketchup
